title.rendered: Move to Canada with Visa Sponsorship Insurance and Revenue Officer Jobs | Salary: $10,000+ Annually

content.rendered:
Are you looking for how to make the move to Canada as an Employment Insurance and Revenue Officer? If you’re uncertain about your decision to immigrate to Canada, you’re in the right place.

Canada offers numerous advantages, including abundant job opportunities, competitive salaries, and various benefits for employees. As an Employment Insurance and Revenue Officer, you’ve chosen a respectable and lucrative profession in Canada, and you also have the opportunity to attain permanent residency.

In this guide, we will walk you through the correct path to follow when planning your immigration to Canada as an Employment Insurance and Revenue Officer. We’ll outline the necessary steps for immigration.

Additionally, you will gain insight into the roles and responsibilities of Employment Insurance and Revenue Officers in Canada, including examples of job positions available to them.

Finally, you will discover both the general and specific requirements essential for immigrating to Canada as an Employment Insurance and Revenue Officer.

What is an Insurance and Revenue Officer Job?

Employment Insurance and Revenue Officers play a vital role in overseeing and upholding laws and regulations associated with immigration, customs, border control, tax revenue, employment insurance, and various government benefit services. They are primarily employed by government agencies across Canada.

These professionals are classified under the Canadian National Occupational Classification list, and their NOC code is 1228.

Role of Insurance and Revenue Officers

Employment Insurance and Revenue Officers perform some or all of the following duties;

Excise tax revenue officers

  • Audit accounting records to determine income, exemptions, payable taxes, compliance with reporting regulations and the existence of fraud
  • Examine accounting systems and internal controls of organizations
  • Provide advice on reporting and evaluation methods for goods subject to taxation
  • Prepare briefs and assist in searching and seizing records, and in preparing charges for court cases.

Immigration officers

  • Determine the admissibility of persons seeking entry into Canada by examining documents and conducting interviews
  • Grant landed-immigrant status, admit persons or order detention or deportation
  • Locate and apprehend persons presumed to be infringing on immigration laws
  • Assist in the removal of deported people by seeking authorization from receiving countries and securing necessary travel documents
  • Appear as a witness in cases related to immigration appeals.

Border services officers and customs inspectors

  • Question persons at border points to determine the admissibility of goods and assess duty
  • Inspect baggage to detect undeclared merchandise or contraband
  • Inform manufacturers and shippers of customs laws and procedures
  • Observe the fabrication of articles affected by customs laws and conduct appraisals
  • Board carriers arriving from foreign countries to determine the nature of cargo to ensure compliance with customs and commerce laws
  • Inspect goods imported by mail
  • May arrest and detain individuals suspected of having committed a criminal offence under the Customs Act or certain other designated Criminal Code offences until police intervention is possible.

Government benefits services officers

  • Determine the eligibility of persons applying for government benefits such as Employment Insurance (EI), Canada Pension Plan (CPP) and Old Age Security (OAS)
  • Ascertain the facts on such issues as reasons for loss of employment and availability for work
  • Monitor the payments of benefits and investigate claimants when there appears to be fraud or abuse.

Highest Paying Jobs for Insurance and Revenue Officers

As an Employment Insurance and Revenue officer, you can get employed under any of the following job titles below.

  • Adjudication officer – employment insurance
  • Appeal judge – employment insurance
  • Appeal officer – taxation
  • Assessing officer – taxation
  • Assessing unit head – taxation
  • Audit reviewer – taxation
  • Benefits officer – government services
  • Border Services Officer (BSO)
  • Business expertise advisor – government services
  • Appeal office
  • Business expertise consultant – government services
  • Case review officer – immigration
  • Citizen Services Officer (CSO) – government services
  • Citizenship registration examiner
  • Claims processing officer – immigration
  • Collection agent – government services
  • Coverage and interpretation officer – taxation
  • Customs and excise examiner
  • Customs inspection supervisor
  • Employment insurance agent
  • Employment insurance officer

Inclusion(s)

  • appeal officer

Exclusion(s)

  • Financial auditors and accountants (See 1111 Financial auditors and accountants)
  • Managers responsible for immigration or employment insurance (See 0411 Government managers – health and social policy development and program administration)
  • Managers responsible for taxation revenue or customs (See 0412 Government managers – economic analysis, policy development and program administration)
  • Other financial officers (See 1114 Other financial officers)
  • Social policy researchers, consultants and program officers (See 4164 Social policy researchers, consultants and program officers)

Requirement to immigrate to Canada as an Employment Insurance and Revenue Officer

Your education qualification is a very important requirement if you want to immigrate to Canada as an employment insurance and revenue officer.

This requirement includes;

  •  bachelor’s degree or college diploma is usually required.
  • Several years of related administrative or regulatory experience may be required.
  • Completion of specialized government training is required.

Additional information

  • Progression to managerial positions in these fields is possible with experience.

General Requirements to Immigrate to Work in Canada

The following are the general requirements to immigrate to Canada as a worker. Therefore, as an employment insurance and revenue officer, you must as well meet them to immigrate to Canada. They include:

  1. Language requirements
  2. Age requirements
  3. Education requirements
  4. Arranged employment
  5. Adaptability
  6. Work experience
  7. Your partner’s ability

#1: Language

The first requirement is your ability to speak, write, listen and read English. Therefore, you must show proof of proficiency in English. Normally, you can demonstrate this by presenting a test result from a recognized exam centre.

#2: Age

The second requirement is your age. Before ever you will be allowed to immigrate to Canada as an employment insurance and revenue officer, you must be within the working age in Canada. Generally, the working age in Canada is between 18 and 65 years old. However, for immigration purposes, you must be within 18 and 35 years old.

#3: Education

The third requirement is your academic qualifications. In other words, your educational background. Usually, every worker in Canada must have at least completed secondary school. However, some jobs like computer user support technician jobs may demand more than secondary school education. Therefore, you must have the minimum education requirement to immigrate to Canada as an employment insurance and revenue officer.

#4: Arranged Employment

The third requirement is whether you can get a job offer from a Canadian employer. However, this is not compulsory. Therefore, even without this, you can still immigrate to Canada as a computer user support technician.

#5: Adaptability

The third requirement is your adaptability in Canada. What this means is that you must be able to settle in Canada easily. As a result, you must present a medical report showing that you are fit to live and work in Canada.

#6: Work experience

The sixth requirement is your previous work experience in Canada. This can be in the form of the work you did as a student in Canada. It can also be in the form of a paid internship. You should know that only paid jobs can count as work experience. Therefore, if your job is not a paid job, it cannot be used.

#7: Your partner’s skills

The seventh requirement is your partner’s skills as well as experience. If you can include this, it can get you extra points in the comprehensive ranking system. Therefore, whenever possible add your partner’s skills, education, age and other qualities in your application.

Steps to immigrate to Canada as an Employment Insurance and Revenue Office

  1. Check if you meet the eligibility requirements for immigration to Canada.
  2. Choose the right immigration program that matches your qualifications and goals.
  3. Gather necessary documents, including identification and educational certificates.
  4. Get your education assessed if it was obtained outside Canada.
  5. Take a language proficiency test, such as IELTS or TEF, and achieve the required score.
  6. Create an online profile if applying through the Express Entry system.
  7. Secure a valid job offer from a Canadian employer if required.
  8. Complete the application for your chosen immigration program and submit it with all required documents and fees.
  9. Wait for an Invitation to Apply (ITA) if applying through Express Entry.
  10. Undergo a medical examination and obtain a police clearance certificate.
  11. Attend a biometrics appointment and an interview if requested.
  12. Ensure you have enough settlement funds to support yourself in Canada.
  13. Pay the necessary application and processing fees.
  14. Provide any additional documents requested during the application process.
  15. Receive the Confirmation of Permanent Residence (COPR) upon approval.
  16. Plan your move to Canada and meet entry requirements, if applicable.
  17. Settle in Canada, obtain your Social Insurance Number (SIN), and start your new life as a permanent resident.
